title: The 1% Rule
summary: Focus on making small, incremental improvements every day to achieve remarkable long-term results.

details.content: Tiny improvements compound over time, leading to significant progress. Consistency in small changes is more sustainable and less overwhelming than aiming for drastic transformations.
If you improve by just 1% each day, those gains add up to nearly 37 times better after one year.

content: Identify one small area to improve today.
Track your daily progress, no matter how minor.
Celebrate small wins to stay motivated.
Focus on consistency over perfection.

title: Habit Stacking
summary: Link a new habit to an existing one to make it easier to remember and perform.

details.content: Attaching a new behavior to a well-established habit leverages existing routines, making it easier to adopt new habits without relying on willpower.
After I brush my teeth (current habit), I will meditate for one minute (new habit).

content: Choose a current habit you do daily.
Pair your new habit immediately after the existing one.
Keep the new habit small and specific.
Repeat the sequence consistently.

title: The Four Laws of Behavior Change
summary: A framework for building good habits and breaking bad ones using four key principles: Make it obvious, attractive, easy, and satisfying.

details.content: Understanding these laws helps you design habits that stick and avoid common pitfalls that lead to failure.
To start reading more: Place your book on your pillow (obvious), choose a book you’re excited about (attractive), read one page (easy), and reward yourself after reading (satisfying).

content: Make cues for good habits visible.
Pair habits with enjoyable activities.
Break habits into tiny steps.
Reward yourself immediately after completing the habit.

title: The Two-Minute Rule
summary: Downscale new habits to take two minutes or less to make starting easy and reduce resistance.

details.content: Starting is often the hardest part. Making habits easy to begin increases the likelihood of following through.
If you want to run regularly, start by putting on your running shoes and stepping outside for two minutes.

content: Break down habits to the simplest first step.
Focus on showing up, not perfection.
Allow yourself to stop after two minutes if you want.
Gradually build up from the two-minute version.

title: Environment Design
summary: Shape your surroundings to make good habits easier and bad habits harder.

details.content: Your environment often determines your behavior. Small changes in your surroundings can have a big impact on your habits.
If you want to eat healthier, place fruit on the counter and hide junk food out of sight.

content: Make cues for good habits visible and accessible.
Remove temptations from your environment.
Organize spaces for specific habits (e.g., reading nook).
Automate positive behaviors where possible.

title: Identity-Based Habits
summary: Focus on the type of person you want to become, not just the outcomes you want to achieve.

details.content: When habits are tied to your identity, you’re more likely to stick with them because they become part of who you are.
Instead of saying 'I want to run a marathon,' say 'I am a runner.'

content: Ask yourself, 'Who is the type of person that could achieve this goal?'
Affirm your identity with each small habit performed.
Focus on building evidence for your desired identity.
Let your actions reinforce your self-image.

title: The Goldilocks Rule
summary: Stay motivated by working on tasks that are just the right level of difficulty—not too hard, not too easy.

details.content: Tasks that are too easy lead to boredom, while those that are too hard cause discouragement. The optimal challenge keeps you engaged and motivated.
If you’re learning a language, choose material that is slightly above your current level to stay challenged but not overwhelmed.

content: Adjust the difficulty of your habits as you improve.
Seek feedback to find your optimal challenge zone.
Celebrate progress to maintain motivation.
Switch things up if you feel bored or stuck.
